#Text=Pontiac ( Quebec )
#Text=The Pontiac is in the Outaouais region of the province of Quebec , in Canada .
#Text=There is a Municipality of Pontiac , which groups the town of Luskville and Quyon , and a Pontiac Regional County Municipality ( MRC ) , which is further up the Ottawa River .
#Text=This article covers both .
#Text=Towns
#Text=History
#Text=The area is part of the historical Anishinabegs ( the Algonquins ) territory , which extended all along the Ottawa River , and as far up as Deep River .
#Text=Archeological excavations , suggest a native occupation of the territory beginning between 4,000 and 2,000 BC .
#Text=They were at the centre of a vast trade network across Northeast America .
#Text=Living mainly from fishing , these people lived semi-permanently on certain sites , which includes cemeteries .
#Text=Around 500 AD , the Pointe-Péninsule groups culture was present in the region .
#Text=These groups were organized around hunting and they made tools of stone .
#Text=These groups formed Algonquin bands around 1,000 BCE .

#Text=At the arrival of the Europeans , the Algonquins controlled the Ottawa River , which they called the Kitchisippi ( meaning great river ) , one of the most important commercial waterways of North America .
#Text=However , around 1650 , decimated by the war with the Iroquois and by disease , the Algonquins lose commercial control of the river .
#Text=The Outaouais people ( also called Ottawas ) became the main intermediaries in the fur trades between the French and other native groups further West .
#Text=Around 1670 , in turn the Outaouais people lost their role as intermediaries , as the European trappers went further up the river to collect furs .
#Text=Pontiac , born between 1712 and 1725 , was the most famous Outaouais leader
#Text=He led the Outaouais in the war of the Outaouais Strait , and the rebellion against the English during the War of Conquest .
#Text=Although his name was given to the municipality , it is unlikely that he travelled through here .
#Text=At the end of the 18th century the first Europeans settled on the banks of its headwaters .
#Text=In 1800 , Philemon Wright , an American from the City of Woburn in Massachusetts , moved to the Portages de la Chaudière along with four families related to him .
#Text=He opened numerous construction sites along various rivers in the region , where he exploited forests of red and white pines .
#Text=These trees were used for the masts of ships in the British fleet .
#Text=Already the site of the Sainte-Marie Mission , the village of Quyon was founded in 1848 by John Egan , a lumber baron of the Ottawa Valley and mayor of Aylmer from 1847 to 1855 .
#Text=It derived its name from the Quyon River , a tributary of the Ottawa River that was used by Egan for log-driving .
#Text=" Quio " was derived from the Algonquin word kweia ( pronounced " quia " ) , meaning " smaller river " or " sandy bottom river " .

#Text=Some of the earliest English settlers were Scottish United Empire Loyalists , who were given free land in 1783 by the English Crown to thank them for their loyalty during the American Revolution .
#Text=The area was heavily settled by Irish immigrants during the mid-19th century after the Great Famine forced many to emigrate for their survival .
#Text=The town was incorporated on January 1 , 1875 , and its spelling was changed to " Quyon " to provide a compromise pronunciation equally acceptable to French- and English-speaking residents .
#Text=It experienced a period of prosperity because of the railway built by the Union Forwarding Company .
#Text=Quyon was amalgamated with the neighbouring townships of North Onslow , South Onslow , and Eardley into the municipality of Pontiac in 1975 .
#Text=Talk
#Text=If you speak English you will have no trouble getting around .
#Text=The Pontiac Region is one of the few parts of Quebec with an anglophone majority .

#Text=Fort-Coulonge , Campbell 's Bay and Luskville are very bilingual but many anglophones do n't know how to speak French , especially in Shawville , Portage du Fort and Bristol where there has been several conflicts between local shopkeepers and the Office québécois de la langue française over the province 's language laws .
#Text=By car
#Text=Pontiac is 47 km west of Ottawa : take any of the bridges that cross the Ottawa River and head north to Boulevard des Allumettieres ( Quebec Highway 148 ) and head west .
#Text=By bus
#Text=There is a Transcollines bus service which leaves M - F at 15:30 from the Ottawa Central Bus Station for Fort-Coulonge .
#Text=The bus will stop wherever you need to along route 148 .
#Text=It takes 1hr 10min to get to Luskville ( chemin de l'Eglise ) , and 15min more to get to Quyon ( at Trudeau 's Collision ) . $ 10 - 13 one way ( Dec 2018 ) .
#Text=By plane
#Text=The closest airport is l'Aéroport Exécutif de Gatineau-Ottawa ( YND ) Gatineau Executive Airport whose only scheduled service is a daily Pascan flight from Quebec City ) .
#Text=Air connections are also available in Ottawa ( YOW ) locally and Montréal ( 200 km distant ) ( YUL ) with direct connections to intercity passenger rail at Montréal-Dorval airport .
#Text=By bicycle
#Text=If you wish to stay on paved road , your best route is using the 148 all the way .
#Text=Some parts have a paved shoulder .
#Text=Spanning most of the populated area of the Pontiac MRC , between Quyon and Sheenboro , is the Cycloparc PPJ , an old railway bed turned into a bike path .
#Text=It is exclusive to bicycles , though some ATVs will clandestinely use it .
#Text=This is also designated as route 1 on Quebec 's Route Verte .
#Text=The part off the 148 in Luskville is gravel , however , so it is best to stay on the 148 .
#Text=An easier but longer route to the Cycloparc PPJ is from Kanata ( Ontario ) .
#Text=Head north to take the ferry in Fitzroy Harbour .
#Text=Get around
#Text=You will need access to a vehicle to get around the Pontiac , though there are taxi services .
#Text=Taxi services
#Text=Shawville Taxi & Courier ( in Shawville ) , ☏ +1 819-647-1982 .
#Text=Ben Taxi ( in Fort-Coulonge ) , ☏ +1 819-683-3223 .
#Text=See
#Text=Pontiac County Fair , 2024 Highway 148 , Luskville Falls .
#Text=Thanksgiving weekend ( early to mid-Oct ) .
#Text=Farmers market , local artisans exhibitions .
